question_text: Based on the provided paper content, how do temperature, excess air factor, and residence time influence combustion efficiency and carbon content in residues during fluidized-bed combustion of WPCBs? Provide a detailed explanation of the mechanisms and parameter effects, supported by specific experimental results.
standard_answer: In fluidized-bed combustion of WPCBs, temperature, excess air factor, and residence time critically influence combustion efficiency and residual carbon content through distinct mechanisms. Higher temperatures (800–1400°C) accelerate reaction kinetics by increasing molecular collision frequency and activation energy, promoting complete oxidation of organic components. The excess air factor (1.2–1.9) determines oxygen availability for combustion reactions; insufficient oxygen leads to incomplete combustion, while excessive air can cool the bed, reducing reaction rates. Residence time (0.25–0.75 s) affects the duration for fuel-oxidizer mixing and reaction completion. Experimental results demonstrate optimal conditions at 1200°C, excess air factor of 1.3, and residence time of 0.75 s, where CO concentration in flue gas decreases to approximately 40 mg Nm⁻³ and carbon content in residues falls below 1 wt%. This combination ensures sufficient thermal energy for decomposition, adequate oxygen supply for oxidation, and prolonged contact time for complete carbon conversion, minimizing unburned carbon and maximizing combustion efficiency.

original_text.2: CO concentration in flue gas decreased to ca. 40 mg Nm⁻³ and the carbon content of residues was less than 1 wt% at 1200°C, excess air factor of 1.3 and residence time of 0.75 s.
